content: Diverse intelligence is an emerging field focused on the behavioral competencies of a wide range of active embodiments.

Cellular collectives and their navigation of anatomical space during embryogenesis, regeneration, and cancer suppression can be used as a model system for learning to communicate with unconventional agents.
Bioelectricity can be used as an interface to test ideas related to diverse intelligence, with applications in birth defects, regenerative medicine, and oncology.

Cybernetic (goal-directed) models from behavioral and cognitive science are a better fit for existing data and engineering endpoints in developmental biology and bioengineering than conventional open-loop emergence and complexity models.
Bioengineered synthetic novel life forms raise questions about non-evolutionary origins of properties and setpoints.
